subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple
msgSnippet: Perhaps I have a warped sense of high-test-coverage but I have always taken it to mean ³covering all of the most likely cases and even most of the unlikely
messageBody:
Perhaps I have a warped sense of high-test-coverage but I have always taken
it to mean

³covering all of the most likely cases and even most of the unlikely
cases²

not just

³one test per unit².

With this definition I would assume that approaching 100% is possible, but
getting 100% is improbable. In my 7+ years of unit testing, test-first, and
TDD I have never developed a system in which I would be confident saying I
had 100% test coverage. Maybe I am too much of a skeptic.

Jason


On 8/22/06 10:08 PM, "Dave Brosius" <dbrosius@...> wrote:

>
>
>
>
> I once got flack that some code that was generated from xml wasn't unit
> tested.
> So i updated the parser/generator to generate unit tests too.
>
> 100% coverage.
>
> gigo
